Two Stage - CSS Buttons

Sun Oct 20 2013:

I love UX.

Especially when the benefit is nearly transparent. Great UX makes an action intuitive, even if you've never seen it before, you feel like you have. It just works.

Gumroad has been creating some great user experiences. If you haven't used their checkout process when buying a digital good. You should. And if not, just check out their site to see how clever and easy someone can make a normally annoying process like checking out.

Last week, someone tweeted about their Countdown.js plugin. It gives users a 10 second opportunity to cancel a process. Like a delete button. Once they hit the delete button, the user sees a countdown allowing them to cancel if they click on it.

I loved the idea of making a multi-purpose button. It avoids having to use an ugly alert box, or a distracting modal. But, I felt hesitant to include the countdown, because it added a touch of pressure for the user. Especially since they have probably never seen that functionality before.

It got me thinking. Why not give multiple actions to a single button? The best use case I could think of was confirming an action. And that way I can do most of it in CSS instead of javascript. Which I think provides a better browser experience.

Here's how the finished product would react...

See the Pen Two Stage Button example by adaml (@adamin) on CodePen

The HTML was simple. I started with my standard button.

<button class="danger">Delete</button>

And some simple SCSS (I use bourbon as a mixin library, but you can easily write the full CSS or use compass)

// colors set by variable
$danger-color: hsla(3.71, 58.79%, 32.35%, 1);
$danger-bg: hsla(1.46, 83.67%, 90.39%, 1);
$grey: hsla(0, 0%, 89.8%, 1);
$tabSize: 50px;

// styling the class of the button
.danger {
  background: $danger-bg;
  color: $danger-color;
}

// button style
.button, button {
  position: relative;
  display: inline-block;
  height: $tabSize;
  padding: 0 2em;
  border-radius: 10px;
  border: 0;
  margin: 2em;
  // prevent mobile browsers from styling this button
  @include appearance(none);
  // add transition for smooth color shifting
  @include transition(background 200ms linear);
  &:hover {
    color: darken($danger-color, 5%);
    background: darken($danger-bg, 3%);
  }
  &:focus {
    outline: 0;
  }
}

This gave me a basic style button with a hover effect.

Now, I know I want to give the button some alternate text on the first click. But I need a place to store the data, and the easiest way is inside the element itself with data-attributes. I'm going to need before text, after text, and data for the icon.

So I modified my html to this:

<button data-alt-text="Are you sure?" data-og-text="Delete" data-icon="?" class="danger">Delete</button>

I now have original text as Delete, my alternate text is Undo, and I'm adding a question mark as the icon, but you can use whatever you want.

Using jQuery to modify the text of the button is straight forward.

// caching the list of elements
var $altBtn = $('[data-alt-text]');

// bind the click event to to the set
$altBtn.on('click', function() {

  // cache 'this' object, and its data
  var $this = $(this),
      ogText = $this.data('og-text'),
      altText = $this.data('alt-text');

  // toggle class
  $this.toggleClass('is-clicked');

  // replace the text depending on the class
  $this.hasClass('is-clicked') ?
    $this.text(altText) :
    $this.text(ogText);
});

That's all the javascript we need. And best of all, it allows us to re-use the code wherever we want in our site. Any time we add data-alt-text to one of our elements. They will be added to the array.

If you don't want this behavior, you can go ahead and make the selector more specific.

Now that we have the text and class changing on click. Let's add some styles to the :after pseudo element. (I love the smacss style of prefixing is- before any of my state classes. It makes the intention so much clearer.)

  &:after {
    // this is a cool trick to use the content of an attribute in your content
    content: attr(data-icon);
    background: $danger-bg;
    line-height: $tabSize;
    font-size: 0.9em;
    font-weight: bold;
    font-size: 1.5em;
    top: 0;
    width: $tabSize;
    position: absolute;
    right: 0;
    border-radius: 10px;
    // lets push it behind when its not in use
    z-index: -1;
    @include transition(background, right 200ms linear);
  }

Last, lets add some visual for when the button has the 'is-clicked' class.

  &.is-clicked {
    background: $grey;
    @include border-right-radius(0);
    &:hover {
      background: darken($grey, 2%);
      &:after {
        background: darken($danger-bg, 2%);
      }
    }
    &:after {
      right: -$tabSize;
      // now we want the element in front
      z-index: 1;
      @include border-left-radius(0);
    }
  }

And that's it! We now have a button that shows two different states depending on class.

And the best part, use the jQuery on method, and you can now bind a new click function to the button with an 'is-clicked' class. Then attach your function to the semi-clicked button only!

Sweet.

Deploying to Github Pages With Docpad

Thu Sep 26 2013:

Lately, a lot of developers are shedding the weight of database driven sites for simple projects like blogs and static websites. I've really been enjoying Docpad. It's built on top of node and is a really simple and clean way to generate a static website.

Docpad is similar to Octopress or Jekyll in that it allows you to write posts/pages in actual files, then run a build process to compile your site into a single static folder.

Why Static Websites?

Sometimes, you just don't need anything more than that. If you don't require a database, it's much easier and faster to generate the static pages and let the web server do the work.

You get to take advantage of caching, no database connection, security and simplicity.

Not to mention, not ever having to use the Wordpress post editor again. Writing markdown in your text editor! Heyoo...

Docpad's Build Process

Docpad builds a publish folder called 'out'. That folder is a well organized structure of all your compiled assets in a public root level folder.

It takes care of your templating, your partials, compiles your Sass, Jade, Markdown or whatever you decided to use, and builds it into standard HTML, CSS and Javascript.

Deploying with Docpad

Docpad offers a few different deployment options. I like the Github Pages option for a few reasons:

  • Keeps your entire working and public project in Github
  • Fast, reliable and fully managed servers
  • Versioned, forkable, trackable repos
  • Oh yeah, and it's free!

Github Pages is well covered on their site. But there's a few things you need to know before you decide to host there.

User/Org Pages or Project Pages

You can host your site in one of two ways. As a user/org or as a project. Its pretty self-explanatory. If you want your Pages to be general for your identity. (Think, root public folder...) You probably want to use the user/organization.

If your site is related to a specific project instead. Use the Project Pages.

What's The Difference?

For the viewer, the only difference is the URL. Your user/org page URL will be username.github.io If you set up a project page, the URL will be username.github.io/project.

Technically, there's a couple of differences. User/org pages live in a separate repo, while a project page will only be a separate branch in your project repo.

Github will automatically make any Github Pages Repo Public, so if for any reason your project is Private, you probably want that separate repo for your site.

Project pages are automatically recognized by having a branch called gh-pages in your repo.

However, user/org pages live in the master branch of a repo with the naming convention: username.github.io

Once you've decided which one you're going to go with. Its time to get started.

Install the Github Pages Deploy plugin

In your terminal, navigate to your Docpad site folder and install the plugin:

$ docpad install ghpages

You'll get the npm install reporting:

info: The action completed successfully
info: Shutting down... cya next time!

You can check out the source on the Docpad Github Pages Plugin Page. But don't be deterred by the fact that it says it doesn't yet support user/org pages. Because it does. Out of the box.

Setting up a Project Page

If you want to host it as a project page. You're literally done. Just type:

$ docpad deploy-ghpages --env static

And it will read your remote. And push to a new gh-pages branch! Go to username.github.io/project and soak it in.

Setting up a User/Org Page

If you're going to set up a separate repo, with a user/org page. Go to your Github account and create a new repo called username.github.io. (yes, your username, not the actual string)

After you've created the repo. Open your local repo in github and add the new remote location:

$ git remote add pages git@example.com:my_project.git

I like to call that repo pages. Assuming you have your SSH Keys set up correctly, you should be fine for pushing there automatically.

Now you're going to edit your /docpad.coffee config file. If you don't have a plugins section, add it. Then put your ghpages config below it:

plugins:
  ghpages:
    deployBranch: 'master'
    deployRemote: 'pages'

This tells the gh-pages plugin to push to your remote called 'pages' and do it directly to the branch called 'master'.

Give it a shot!

$ docpad deploy-ghpages --env static

It should automatically set up your 'static' environment and push your code to your 'pages' repo.

Don't forget to commit all your changes to your 'working' repo as well though.

$ git push origin master

Conclusion

That's it. You now have a full deployment process to Github Pages on your Docpad site. Let me know if you have any questions...

Preparing Your Website For Deployment

Fri Sep 20 2013:

One of the practices that's really been improving in the javascript/css/html world is build processes.

If you're on the beginning side of web development, they can be an intimidating thing. But if you focus on understanding what it is first. It becomes a lot easier to implement.

What is a build process

The easiest way to think of a build process is -- running an action on your files to help prepare them for production.

We use lots of shortcuts, and libraries, and tricks in our development, and web servers don't need to see them. And in a lot of cases, won't know what to do with the files anyway.

But developing is so much better with separation, shortcuts and organization, we can't let THAT stop us from using it.

So instead. We configure a helper to take the files, lint, compress, concatenate and copy the files into a pretty and organized folder full of html, css and javascript. Exactly how a web server wants to read its' files.

Structure

Using a build process will allow you to separate your 'working folder', where you do your coding, from your 'production folder' that the web server will read.

Some common naming conventions for the two folders:

  • src/out
  • app/dist
  • working/build
  • pre/public
  • etc...

They can have any names, it's just important for them to be obvious.

Features

Build processes can do a lot of things. And any time its automated, you're decreasing your chance of making a mistake. And giving yourself more time to write code!

Compiling

  • Write your code in SASS, CoffeeScript, Jade, or anything you like.
  • You can easily configure your build script to compile that code into standard html, css and javascript

Compressing

  • Running your code through 'minifiers', will take those easy to read variables, and those beautiful line breaks, and squash them into a single 'ugly' line.
  • Why? Filesize baby. Cutting out those extra letters is less for a server to think about
  • There's no actual benefit for a computer to read them pretty. They just don't care. Better to have it load as quickly as possible instead.

Concatenating

  • Likewise, while its ideal to separate your CSS and Javascript files into smaller pieces so you can use them more easily. Again, your server just doesn't care
  • Concatenating will combine your files into a single file of that type, and only have to load it once.
  • This is way better for performance as limiting http requests is always a good thing.

Copying

  • Move your compressed and concatenated files into a folder structure that makes more sense for URLs instead of what works best for you

Linting

  • These scripts can scan your code for common errors, missed punctuation, spelling etc...
  • Trust me, now matter how good a developer is, they will make mistakes! Linters, always catch them.

Tools

While you can write these build scripts yourself. If you're reading this article, you probably need some practice in using them first. Here's some build script libraries to get you started.

  • GruntJS -- An awesome task manager in javascript
  • Brunch -- An equally awesome collection of build processes
  • Codekit -- An incredible GUI for build processes

And lots of site building frameworks have it built in!

  • Yeoman -- A workflow for building modern apps
  • Docpad -- A framework for building static sites (That's what I use here)
  • Asset Pipeline -- Rails build process for Javascript/CSS
  • Octopress -- A cool static site generator that works with Github Pages

There's a lot more out there. But I've personally used, and can vouch that these ones are great. But definitely explore everything out there!

Conclusion

It might be a hurdle to get into using a build system. But once you do. Trust me. You will never build a site without one again.

Helpful Links
  • Website Deployment: Let us count the ways! -- When you have that deployment folder locked down. This is a great article on what to do next
  • Setting Up A Build Process For JavaScript & CSS Files by Addy Osmani -- A great screencast that really got me caught up with Build Processes. (He uses Ant. I wouldn't advise it for your first build process, but it has lots of good info)

Styles Seed Explained

Sun Sep 15 2013:

Whether I'm doing tests, hackathons or full-fledged projects, I like to set up my css structure in a way that makes sense to me. It allows me to quickly understand and edit my styles at any time.

After a lot of repeating boilerplate, I decided to create Styles Seed. Although I usually write in SASS, I also provide a version in SCSS. If you prefer Stylus, or even LESS, its easy to convert. When I have the time, I'll make a build process to do it for me.

Styles Seed is inspired by SMACSS, Nicole Sullivan's OOCSS, and way too many years of building CSS layouts.

Structure

styles
|
|---lib.scss                 // for reusing mixins and vars
|---mixins.scss              // custom mixins
|---vars.scss                // localized variables
|
|---global.scss              // the manifest file
|
|---> global            // all modular css should have a home here
|   |---base.scss
|   |---buttons.scss
|   |---icons.scss
|   |---layout.scss
|   |---modules.scss
|   |---state.scss
|   └---typography.scss
|
|---> vendor            // for storing vendor/library files
|
|---> modules           // for reusable module css
|   |---footer.scss
|   |---header.scss
|   |---forms.scss
|
|---static.scss              // for css that will be loaded separately
|
|---ie.scss                  // for that super fun part of writing ie only css

Global File

I run all of my reusable code through a file called global.scss. This is my manifest file where I control all of my importing.

Don't forget, although @import in live CSS is bad, using it in a precompiled language like SASS works perfect.

// my CSS reset of choice
@import "vendor/normalize.scss";

// reused in all separate stylesheets
@import "lib";

// modular css
@import "global/base";
@import "global/layout";
@import "global/buttons";
@import "global/icons";
@import "global/typography";
@import "global/state";

// less repeatable rules go here
@import "global/modules";

Global.scss is my main switchboard. I try to keep 95% of my code as reusable so it all goes in here. It gets compiled into a single global.css file that I load right into my html. Its linted, compressed, and ready to for production.

<link  rel="stylesheet" href="/styles/global.css" />

Inside it, I import:

normalize.scss -- My CSS reset of choice. There are a few resets and variants out there. But Normalize, by Nicolas Galagher is great.

lib folder -- imports 3 things.

  • My mixin library bourbon or compass
  • vars.scss This is where I store all the variables related to my project
  • mixins.scss a library of my custom mixins

Its important to note that all of the files in this folder are library files. Meaning they don't actually create any CSS. They are a list of variables and templates that can be used when creating your CSS.

I keep this folder separate because any single-standing SCSS files that I want to use later, can also import this library, without me worrying about duplicating CSS.

SMACSS Files -- All my basic SMACSS files go here. They're simple and straight forward. These cover most of the site's styles.

Modules -- I do separate out my modules. I know this isn't standard SMACSS. But I like to because it just makes things easier to find. Its where I put things like header.scss, footer.scss, nav.scss etc...

No Shame

I admit it. I do like the idea of a shame folder. I had always used a temp.scss file for quick edits that needed to be moved later. Before there was a clever name for it.

But one of the real advantages of being comfortable with this structure is I no longer need to think about it. I can place my code in the appropriate file just as fast as I can put them in a blame file.
